author: FredWeedMax
body:
They seem to perform very similarly (lots of similar holdings %)

since inception SOXX performed 30 points better than SMH (240% vs 210%)

but since jan 2019 SMH performed a tiny bit better (64.55% vs 62.14% for soxx)

Similarly smh performed 0.5 points better than soxx from oct 3 onwards (22.39% for smh vs 21.93% for soxx)

SMH has a lot more TSM and INTC than SOXX, similarly SOXX has more NVDA TXN QCOM and AVGO than SMH

author: mdirx
body:
Companies with a 64-bit ARMv8-A architectural license include Applied   Micro,Broadcom, Cavium,Huawei (HiSilicon), Nvidia, AMD,Qualcomm, Samsung, and Apple.

Companies with a 32-bit Arm architectural license include Broadcom (ARMv7), Faraday Technology (ARMv4, ARMv5), Marvell Technology Group, Microsoft, Qualcomm, Intel, and Apple.

My top 6 would be:

LMT (16 yrs of consecutive increases)

AVGO (great dividend yield and has more upside potential)

NEE (excellent track record and good management)

DIS (another great long-term stock)

ABBV (management says that they're focused on increasing dividends for years to come and the yield is over 5%)

MSFT (many years of consecutive increases and they also constantly buy back shares/EPS keep rising)

author: FredWeedMax
body:
AVGO taking a dump today on seemingly no news while the rest of the semis, the market and SMH are going up.

Sitting around 305 right now from which it already rebounded 3 times since the breakout of november. It also rebounded on that support back in April and got rejected a bunch of times in july and september so it seems like it's a good support

There's a gap left to 296.59 tho so it might visit that area first but that'd be another 2.5% downside. Next big volume area is 290 but again that's way too low point of entry for a technical move like that.

It seems like failure to make it past 313 was what triggered the selloff this morning

author: ChamberofSarcasm
body:
Also, tech has bought back more shares than any industry (in the last few years). 

"from SocGen's Sophie Huynh (this is from a November note):

>The level of concentration of tech buybacks is rather extreme: the top 10 buybacks represent 83% of total sector buybacks, rising to 90% for the top 15. This means the trend is driven by a few companies such as Apple, Oracle, Qualcomm, Microsoft, Broadcom, Alphabet and Intel. We can see this in the S&P 500, where no fewer than eight tech companies figure among the top 15 buyback programs. We still expect tech companies to continue dominating the buybacks spectrum (currently 31% of S&P 500 gross buybacks) but the levels should gradually normalize from the abnormal amounts due to Trump’s end-2017 tax reforms through cash repatriation and the boost to US GDP"  
>  
>[https://seekingalpha.com/article/4317967-sixth-porsche](https://seekingalpha.com/article/4317967-sixth-porsche)

author: alwayswashere
body:
the stock price has come a long way. and you could have said the same thing when it grew to $5. and then $10, $20... and you would have continued to be short sighted as you are being now. data and compute appetite are growing at an astonishing rate at a consistent pace ever since we started storing and processing bits decades ago and its not going to slow down.

Lisa has shown that AMD has a consistent roadmap to consistently demolish intel CPU for at least another 2-3 years. after that, i trust AMD will not shoot themselves in the foot again with a risky new arch like bulldozer was. at worst case intel will only catch up.

another major factor here is foundry (node) advantage. unless intel can overtake TSMC (and samsung... and all the other foundrys) they wont surpass AMD. the best they can do is dump their foundry and outsource to TSMC. its just not possible for intel to spend what TSMC can on node R&D. TSMC is effectively a factor of the R&D budgets from apple, qualcomm, nvidia, amd, mediatek, marvell, broadcom, xlinix, huawei...

if you have the vision to realize what AMD can and most likely will accomplish, you would buy in at these levels without hesitation. if you are running a fund... the big and smart money... you are not interested in day trading. they want a nice stock that will have consistent growth for a minimum of two years. a growth company. they want an industry that is expanding. they are not looking at the past, they are looking forward to 2+ years ("TTM PE" vs "forward PE"), to when earnings will be around $5/share (at this rate) from a dominant company with almost zero debit and the best track recordd of any stock over the last two years.

all aboard! (reposted from /r/amd_stock cause it fits here)

author: xlynx
body: No, I meant ARM, the processor architecture family. Within this, there are competing ARM architectures from licencees like APPL, QCOM, MTSI, STM, SMSN, MCHP, AVGO, XLNX, TXN, NXP, NVDA, MRVL. Most of these are scaling down for embedded microcontrollers. But some, like APPL, QCOM, NVDA, MRVL are scaling up for laptops, desktops, and servers.

author: cballowe
body:
Most analysts are looking at trends in the market, earnings announcements from similar/correlated companies, product and press news, and predictions from other analysts. The big firms would have asset specialists, industry specialists, etc.

If you're looking for your own research, you can go down the rabbit hole on any of those.

For aapl, you might think about their suppliers (possible leading indicator), whether they have new products (and how those affect earnings historically), any other related companies that have announced recently (what did Samsung, Intel, broadcom, at&t, etc report most recently). You could look at other analysts estimates and try to confirm their assumptions with your own research.
